newsitem.title: KENYA: Kenya scraps insurance cos' capital gains tax.
newsitem.headline: Kenya scraps insurance cos' capital gains tax.

text.p: Kenyan Finance Minister Musalia Mudavadi has scrapped a capital gains tax imposed on insurance companies' holdings of Nairobi Stock Exchange (NSE)-listed shares, a move industry officials saw as very progressive.
In his budget presentation to parliament on Thursday, Mudavadi said he removed the 35-percent tax to help capital markets grow and boost Kenya's status as an emerging market.
He also reduced stamp duty on primary issues by 60 percent on the NSE, but did not say what the new rate was.
Insurance companies and NSE executives said Mudavadi's measures were tailored to improve liquidity in the market and help create a more vibrant bourse.
"It's a very welcome development, which should be able to stir up insurance companies to trade actively in our market," said NSE chief executive Job Kihumba.
NSE capitalisation stands at $2.28 billion. About 20 to 25 percent is illiquid stock held by insurance companies who for a long time have adopted a buy-and-hold policy, officials said.

Ashok Shah, managing diretor at Apollo Insurance, said "we can now start trading (on the bourse). For a long time, the insurance industry was the only industry taxed for the profits made on investment."
The capital gains tax imposed on exchange-listed stocks was seen as punitive since individuals were not taxed on investment gains made at the NSE.
"There is a lot of interest in Kenya as an emerging market from foreigners, but a major problem we have had is the unavailability of stocks," a senior broker said.
But NSE chairman Jimnah Mbaru said reduction of stamp duty would cut the cost of raising capital on the bourse.
